Exercise Description: Stand tall and perform stiff-legged skips by driving one knee upward sharply while keeping the opposite leg straight, landing on the ball of the foot. Continue for four or five skips, then transition immediately into a forward sprint. Keep posture tall and foot contacts quick to prime sprint mechanics.

Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart and hands placed on your hips or at your sides for balance. Shift your weight slightly onto one leg while lifting the opposite knee to about hip height. From this position, draw a large, controlled circular motion with your lifted knee, moving outward and then downward before bringing it back to the starting position. Reverse the movement after completing all reps in one direction. Keep your core engaged, and ensure your hips remain square to the front without excessive torso movement.

Attach a resistance band to a sturdy anchor at elbow height. Stand sideways to the anchor and hold the band with your outside hand. Keeping your elbow tucked to your side at 90 degrees, rotate your forearm outward against the band’s resistance. Hold the end range briefly before slowly returning to the start. Avoid using your shoulder or upper body to assist; the movement should come from the rotator cuff muscles.

Lie flat with knees bent and feet hip-width apart. Lift hips into a full bridge and hold. While keeping hips completely level, raise one knee slowly towards the chest over 3 seconds. Pause briefly, then return over 3 seconds. Alternate sides. Avoid any hip drop, twist or trunk movement during each march.

Place a barbell on your back. Drop as fast as possible into a 90 degree angle from the floor. Stop as quickly as possible at this point, then push upwards with force. Try to get into a consistent rhythm for the entire reps in the set.

Exercise Name: Deceleration Lunge - Med Ball Throw and Leap
Exercise Description: Hold a medicine ball at chest height and start in a split squat position. Bring you front foot up off the ground and out in front. Let gravity drop you into a deep lunge position while at the same time, extending the arms and forcefully pushing the med ball as far as possible straight ahead. Maintain balance and stability in the lunge position, keeping the chest tall and knee aligned over the foot. Focus on controlled deceleration with a strong, direct throw.

Exercise Name: Nothing unless under 60 minutes match time

Exercise Description: Stand facing away from the throwing direction with an 8kg medicine ball held in both hands. Plant your feet shoulder-width apart. Squat slightly to generate power, then explosively drive through your legs and hips while throwing the ball overhead and backwards as far as possible. Use a strong upward and backward motion with your arms to maximise the throw distance. Maintain control of your body throughout the movement and ensure a safe area behind you for the throw.

Exercise Name: Single-Leg Wall Sit with Overhead Reach
Exercise Description: Lean against a wall in a seated position with thighs parallel to the floor. Extend one leg straight out in front of you while holding the wall sit on the other. Reach both arms overhead and hold. Keep your lower back pressed into the wall and avoid arching. Maintain even pressure through the planted foot and focus on stability in both the hips and shoulders.

Start with the barbell on a squat rack at shoulder height. Position it across your upper back while gripping the bar slightly wider than shoulder-width. With feet shoulder-width apart, lift the bar off the rack and step back into position. Keep your chest up and core engaged as you lower into a squat, ensuring your thighs are parallel to the ground or deeper. Push through your heels to return to standing. Gradually add weight to determine your one-rep maximum

Overview: The aim in this phase is to transfer force through the kinetic chain without apply antecedental forces to prevent the power.  This will mix both biomechanical work together and with the specific movements of exercises that will naturally align movement. Succesful transfer will be seen in movement and specifically shots and touches.

Exercise Description: Begin standing tall. Step forward at a 45-degree angle and reach both arms forward. Return to start, then step laterally and reach the arms overhead. Return again and then step back diagonally, reaching the arms across the body. Perform each movement smoothly, focusing on joint control, weight shift and balance. Alternate legs with each full cycle.

Position yourself on all fours facing a wall, with your hands under your shoulders and knees under your hips. Lift your knees just off the ground so that they hover an inch or two above the floor – keeping your back flat and core braced. Now press each hand firmly against the wall in front of you while your feet stay planted. Hold this position by actively pressing into the wall with your palms and pushing your heels backwards as if dragging the floor. The goal is full tension across the core, shoulders and hips while maintaining perfect posture. Keep the neck neutral and avoid arching through the lower back. Breathe steadily while holding. If unable to complete without affecting your posture, drop the duration but focus on the technique.

Stand 1–2 metres from a wall. Balance on one side with the opposite foot raised in front. Perform short, controlled volleys against the wall using the raised foot. Keep the standing side stable with minimal hip shift or knee collapse. Trunk and ankle should stay firm throughout. Reset your posture after each volley if needed to maintain balance.

Begin lying flat on a bench, feet firmly planted on the ground. Grip the barbell slightly wider than shoulder-width and lift it off the rack, holding it above your chest with arms fully extended. Lower the barbell to your chest in a controlled motion, keeping your elbows at a 45-degree angle, then press it back up to the starting position. Incrementally increase the weight to identify your one-rep maximum.

Stand tall with your feet hip-width apart. Engage your core and ensure your posture is upright. Start by hopping forward on one foot, always keeping the other foot off the ground. As you hop, swing one arm forward and one arm back to maintain balance and mimic running mechanics. After completing the hops on one side, switch to your other foot and repeat the same process. Keep in mind, that arms must swing opposite to the hop, mimicking the natural arm swing during running. Aim for a rhythmical, springy hop rather than a high or long jump. Your landing foot should spring off the ground as soon as it touches down, emphasising the reactive strength component. After completing the first set on both sides moving forward, do the same moving left and then moving right. Each time, you should keep minimal ground contact time as the focus, rather than height or distance.

Stand with one foot on a slider and the other flat on the ground. Slowly slide the foot out into a lateral lunge, keeping the planted foot still and bending that knee while the slider leg stays straight. At the bottom, push through the planted leg to pull yourself back in, lifting the slider foot off the ground into a single-leg balance. Keep the chest lifted and control both the lunge and return phase.

As the ball rolls, fake the shot and let it continue into your next stride. If the defender is still in front of you, push the ball another 3-yards into space and slightly across the defender, using a stiff arm or leap across to stay in front of them and first to the ball. From there finish on the next touch. You can utilise a toe punt finish if you have little space or time to work with.

Start in an athletic stance with knees slightly bent and torso upright. From the start, turn immediately and take your first step out at a 90-degree angle. Maintain upright posture through the turn and accelerate quickly, using fast hip rotation and a powerful push-off to reach top speed early.

Begin in a hip hinge position with your chest slightly forward and hips loaded. Take your first step out at a 45-degree angle, staying low and driving your back hip around the corner to accelerate into a sprint towards the side (90 degrees from the start position).

Propel yourself forwards and land on one foot with your weight shifted slightly forward. Immediately recoil with a backwards leap as far as possible. Focus on turning your hips in on the initial step and then opening them full the opposite direction on the backwards leap.

Exercise Name: Lateral 90-Degree Turn Hop into Box Jump into Drop Jump
Exercise Description: Stand side-on to a plyo box. Perform a lateral hop and rotate 90 degrees mid-air to face the box. Land softly just in front of it on both feet, then immediately spring into a vertical box jump. After landing on top, jump forwards off the other side of the box and control the landing after. Aim to stick the landing but use small bounces to dissipate the energy where necessary.

Begin in a crouched, low athletic stance. Take short, fast steps forward while staying low, then gradually rise into a tall sprinting posture with high knee drive and upright mechanics. Focus on seamless transition from low acceleration steps to full-height sprint form. Keep steps powerful and posture smooth as you shift levels.

Notes: Perform Daily Prehab (Session A) every day in which you are not feeling high levels of soreness. Perform Conditioning (Session H) twice per week either altogether, or split up individually after other sessions.

Exercise Description: Stand with feet shoulder-width apart. Swing your arms back while bending your knees slightly, then explosively jump forward, maximising horizontal distance. Land softly on both feet and measure the jump.

If driving laterally across the pitch towards one sideline, broaden your plant foot's distance from the ball and ensure it plants facing towards the goal. Whip your back hip around and through the ball while aiming slightly wide of the far post. Aim for an in-swing that carries the ball into the far corner of the goal.
Notes: Start by receiving in the half-space having pulled out diagonally to offer for the ball. Roll to the inside and drive with 3-yard touches out of your feet. Open into the appropriate finish depending on the angle from goal that you are driving.

Exercise Description: Stand side-on a short distance away from a wall in an athletic stance. Push off the outside foot, turning 90 degrees as you accelerate forward along the wall’s edge. Use the wall as a barrier to keep your line tight and posture square. Sprint out with powerful first steps and maintain hip rotation speed. Focus on quick turn-in and aggressive acceleration.

Stand perpendicular to a cable machine with the handle attached to the low pulley. Hold the handle with both hands at hip height and step away from the machine to create tension. Rotate your torso and hips towards the machine, pivoting on your outside foot to add more twist to the movement. Then, quickly rotate away from the machine, switching your grip mid-swing, and punch the handle forward (away from the machine) as you finish the rotation, fully extending your arms. Control the return as you rotate back to the starting position, keeping tension on the cable and maintaining a strong core.

If driving on an angle slightly towards goal up to directly at goal, plant close to the ball while loading heavily into the plant foot. Follow through low-to-mid height past the ball and aim down the centre of the goal.  You can lift the plant foot off the ground in contrast to the shooting foot after the ball is shot for further power. The aim is to have the ball drop or decelerate only momentarily before it reaches the ball and for any swaz to carry it towards the corners rather than past the posts.

Exercise Name: Backwards Power Step to Forwards Leap
Exercise Description: Propel yourself backwards and land on one foot with your weight kept shifted slightly forward. Immediately recoil with a forwards leap as far as possible.

Set up an M-shape with cones (10m
vertically, 5m horizontally in total - middle of the M 2.5m in). Sprint along the M itself from point to
point and then back to the start as fast as possible.

If driving and unable to open space to shoot or taking an improper set-up touch to finish, exaggerate a fake shot before continuing to drive. Utilise a reversed finish aiming down the centre of the goal but while fully whipping the back hip around the ball such that is is carried into the inside of the near post.

Stand tall with one foot in front and the other behind in a split stance. Jump vertically, switching legs in mid-air and land with the opposite foot forward in the split stance. Keep torso upright and land softly before repeating. Focus on height, crisp leg switch, and balance on each landing.

Begin in a slightly bladed stance with one foot in front and the other behind, both roughly shoulder-width apart. From this position, shift your weight quickly forward and backward between both feet in a continuous bouncing motion by rotating at the hips towards the direction you want to shift your weight. Move forwards or backwards a few inches with each jump. Keep the movements light and reactive, using the balls of your feet to minimise ground contact.

As the ball rolls, fake the shot and let it continue into your next stride before finishing. Exaggerate the fake shot such that the defender gets big and is unable to stay in front on the actual shot.
Notes: Start in a 1v1 either triple threat to feet or receiving on the edge of the box. Cut either inside or outside with a 3-yard touch then apply one of the variations.

Exercise Description:
Set a watt bike to
level-3 resistance. The aim is to achieve the highest average cadence / watts across a 30-minute period.
Only one attempt is needed to gauge your score for this test.

Exercise Name: Diagonal Drop Step into Vertical Jump
Exercise Description: Step diagonally out in front and to one side and bend at the knee to drop lower to the ground. Sink your weight through this plant foot to load up, then immediately push through the ground to jump vertically as high as possible.

Start upright in an athletic position. Take your first step out at a 90-degree angle, opening the hips, for the back hip to then drive around the corner to crossover step, bringing the outside leg across the body to land in front. The inside leg can then extend while turning the outside hip to reverse the direction and accelerate out.

Set up a phone or device with a random flashing colour display, assigning each colour to a specific cone positioned around you. Stand in a neutral upright position centrally. When a colour flashes, perform a quick jab step towards the cone that corresponds to that colour, then return immediately to the neutral position. Keep movements sharp and reactive, staying balanced and ready for the next cue.

Exercise Name: Long Lever Copenhagen with Hip Drop and Drive
Exercise Description: Set up with your top leg supported on a bench, bottom leg hovering beneath. Extend the body fully in a straight line and brace the core. Lower your hips slowly towards the floor under control, then drive the hips back up forcefully to return to parallel. Keep the shoulders stacked, top leg straight and avoid twisting. This develops eccentric adductor strength with control.

As the ball rolls, fake the shot and let it continue into your next stride. If the defender is still in front of you, stop the ball on the spot or slightly cut it back the direction you came, before immediately taking another 3-yard touch to continue in the initial direction and open into the finish.

Stand tall and step laterally with one foot. Lower into a squat, keeping your chest upright, and open your hips to that side. Push through your heels to return to standing and repeat on the opposite side.

Begin in a hip hinge position with your chest slightly forward and hips loaded. Take your first step out at a 45-degree angle, staying low and driving your back hip around the corner to crossover step, bringing the outside leg across the body to land in front. The inside leg can then extend while turning at the hip to reverse the direction and accelerate out. Stay low and push off forcefully to accelerate while keeping your torso over your hips.

Stand in the middle of the trap bar with feet shoulder-width apart. Bend at your hips and knees while keeping your back straight and chest up. Grip the handles of the trap bar firmly, engage your core, and drive through your heels to lift the bar to a standing position. Lower the bar back down in a controlled manner. Progressively increase the weight to find your maximum lift.

Begin in a sprint acceleration and take 2–3 powerful steps. As you approach the box set in your path, place one foot naturally onto the box mid-stride. Push explosively off the box to project yourself forward and continue sprinting without breaking rhythm. Sprint for a further 10 metres beyond the box before decelerating under control. Focus on smooth integration of the box step within the stride and aggressive drive out.

Sprint all out until you can no longer
sustain maximum speed. Measure the number of
seconds until this point is reached.

Begin in a standing position with feet shoulder-width apart. Drop quickly into a squat by bending your knees and hips, then immediately explode upwards into a vertical jump. Land softly with knees slightly bent, ready to reset for the next repetition.

Stand side-on a short distance away from a wall in an athletic stance. Push off the outside foot, turning 90 degrees as you accelerate forward along the wall’s edge. Use the wall as a barrier to keep your line tight and posture square. Sprint out with powerful first steps and maintain hip rotation speed. Focus on quick turn-in and aggressive acceleration.

Sprint 40 metres
all out from a standstill and measure the time it takes to reach each of these splits. Use speed gates for accuracy, or otherwise film with a cone to mark
each distance and take the times afterwards. Retain
only the splits from the fastest 40 metre sprint (note that this is metres not yards).

Start in a push-up position with your hands under your shoulders. Without bending your elbows, squeeze your shoulder blades together, lowering your chest slightly. Then, push through your hands and round your upper back as your shoulder blades spread apart.

Stand tall with your arms extended at your sides. Swing both arms forward across your chest in a hugging motion, then open them wide again behind your body. Continue alternating swings in a rhythmic fashion, crossing one arm over the other on each rep. Maintain a relaxed posture and allow your shoulders to move freely. This is a light dynamic movement used to activate the upper body.

As the ball rolls, fake the shot and let it continue into your next stride. If the defender is still in front of you, stop the ball on the spot or slightly cut it back the direction you came, before immediately cutting 3-yards back toward the direction you came (and angled slightly towards goal) before opening into the finish.

Start from a static squat position, knees bent at a 90-degree angle. Engage your core and explosively jump vertically as high as you can. Land softly, returning to the squat position. Measure the jump height or use video footage for analysis.

Exercise Name: Reverse Nordic Curl (Short ROM for Quads)
Exercise Description: Kneel on a padded surface with feet anchored or flat against the floor. Keep your torso tall, squeeze your glutes and slowly lean back by extending through the knees, lowering your body in a straight line. Go only as far as you can control, then return to upright. Keep the hips extended and avoid breaking at the waist. Focus on tension through the quads and control through the eccentric phase.

Start with feet shoulder-width apart. Perform three consecutive jumps, taking off and landing with both feet each time. Focus on maximising horizontal distance with each jump while maintaining control.
